citeinfo.title: INDUSTRIAL_MINERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN: Active Industrial Mineral Operations in 2001 in Indiana (Indiana Geological Survey, Point Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit: This shapefile was derived from a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet (ActiveMines2001.xls) provided by Kathy Shaffer, Indiana Geological Survey.

descript.abstract: INDUSTRIAL_MINERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN is a point shapefile that shows the locations of industrial mineral operations that were active in 2001 in Indiana. These operations extracted and (or) produced the following commodities: cement, clay and shale, crushed stone, dimension limestone, dimension sandstone, gypsum, lime, peat, and sand and gravel.
descript.purpose: INDUSTRIAL_MINERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN was created to provide a multi-county digital shapefile, suitable for use in a GIS.

attracc.attraccr: The data contained in this shapefile was extracted from a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet named "ActiveMines2001" produced by the Industrial Minerals Section of the Indiana Geological Survey. This spreadsheet is assumed to be complete and correct.

dataqual.complete: This shapefile represents more than 90 percent of industrial mineral operations that were active in Indiana in 2001. Some operations may have been omitted that were not subject to federal or state regulation because of their relatively small size and (or) because of their lack of adverse effects on the environment.

horizpa.horizpar: The data contained in this shapefile were collected using a Trimble GeoExplorer III GPS receiver and was differentially corrected using the Indiana Geological Survey's base station data. Trimble states that no more than (plus/minus) 1 to 5 feet of error when GPS data is differentially corrected.

vertacc.vertaccr: The vertical positional accuracy was not a factor in the digital production of INDUSTRIAL_MINERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN.

procstep.procdesc: During the summer of 2001, staff of the Mineral Resources Section of the Indiana Geological Survey conducted field work to collect mine location data using a Trimble GeoExplorer III GPS unit. These data were downloaded to Trimble Pathfinder Office for processing and exported as an ESRI ArcView shapefile. The theme attribute table was converted to a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet named "ACTIVEMINES2001.XLS." Company and commodity data from the 2001 Directory of Industrial Mineral Producers in Indiana were directly entered into that spreadsheet.
procstep.srcused: Active industrial minerals operation in study area.XLS

procstep.procdesc:
The Microsoft Excel spreadsheet ACTIVEMINES2001.XLS was saved as a dBase III file named "ACTIVEMINES2001.DBF." The file ACTIVEMINES2001.DBF was added to an ESRI ArcView project as a table. The "Add Event Theme" and "Convert to Shapefile" functions were used to import the table into an ArcView View and to convert the table to a shapefile INDUSTRIAL_MINDERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN.
The shapefile INDUSTRIAL_MINDERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN was then edited in ESRI ArcView. Of the 363 records in ACTIVEMINES2001.XLS there were 320 records that had complete locational information in the form of UTMx and UTMy coordinates. Records without such locational information were deleted from the shapefile. Of the 320 records with complete locational information, there were 314 records that had complete information regarding the name of the mine, pit, quarry, plant, and (or) company. Points lacking such information were deleted from the shapefile.
Additional editing of the shapefile INDUSTRIAL_MINDERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN was then conducted. The following fields were added: Commodity1, Commodity2, and Commodity3. Using the "Calculator" function, values in the field named "Commodity1" were set equal to values in the field named "Type." Records having no locational information but that had company information were used to fill in the fields Commodity2 and Commodity3. Finally, the following fields were then removed from the shapefile: Type, Quadrangle, Qtr, Sec, T, R, County_nam, Longitude, Latitude, and Number.

This metadata was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit) and MP (Metadata Parser) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (United States Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected, except that no values were assigned to "Abscissa_Resolution" and "Ordinate_Resolution."
